revised_title: Post-tetanic Enhancement of Action Potential in Mammalian Nerve Fibres
tldr: The authors studied the effects of activity on mammalian nerve fibers of low conduction velocity. They discovered that repetitive stimulation enhances the action potential in nerves conducting at velocities less than 1.1 m/s. This phenomenon, called post-tetanic enhancement, is caused by hyperpolarization of the nerve after repetitive excitation. The authors suggest that this property is common to all mammalian non-myelinated nerve fibers and is responsible for post-tetanic facilitation in junctional tissues.
